channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-20928] Rewrite calculation of midpoint in binarySearch functions to prevent overflow
item.description:
There are couple of issues in the function:

  • >>> operator would mess the values if low + high end up being negative. This shouldn't happen but I don't see anything to prevent this from happening.
  • The code fails around boundary values of low and high. This is a well known binary search catch. https://ai.googleblog.com/2006/06/extra-extra-read-all-about-it-nearly.html

 

Most of the code should already be covered by tests. I would have liked to add a test that actually fails without the fix but given these are private methods I am not sure on the best place to add the test. Suggestions?
item.summary: Rewrite calculation of midpoint in binarySearch functions to prevent overflow

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
There is similar issue with Bytes#binarySearch .

Mind fixing that method as well ?
Attached the patch for similar fix throughout the repo.

yuzhihong@gmail.com How do I retrigger the validation on the new patch?

On https://builds.apache.org/job/PreCommit-HBASE-Build, you can see two running instances.

One of them is for your patch:
https://builds.apache.org/job/PreCommit-HBASE-Build/13756/parameters/

You can wait for the above to come back. Since hbase-server module is touched, the test run would take longer.

The cited article explicitly states that

int mid = (low + high) >>> 1;

is OK and likely faster. I'm somewhat confused then about this change, especially since said article is given as the reason.

stack, fyi.

I'm testing HBase 2 again HBase 1 right now and find that its scan performance is 50% worse in many cases (with ROW_INDEX_V1 at least). Not saying this is causing this, but it came up as a change in that code path.

description.
I can investigate the perf impact of this change but I find it really
surprising that it could shift the baseline by 50%

On Mon, Jan 14, 2019, 11:51 AM Lars Hofhansl (JIRA) <jira@apache.org wrote:

Hey bashrc-real, I'm not saying that this is causing the slow down. It just showed up when a "git blamed" some of the relevant code paths. In fact I do not thing this is causing such a slow-down.

But I did notice that the article you link in the description does say that "int mid = (low + high) >>> 1;" is correct and faster. That's what we had. Why do we need to change it?
In a microbenchmark I actually found that >>> is slightly slower (JDK 8). No need to change it back.
